F, f
/ ef; Zf/ n (pl F's, f's / efs; Zfs/)  1 the sixth letter of the English alphabet Ó¢Óï×ÖÄ¸±íµÄµÚÁù¸ö×ÖÄ¸: `Fabric' starts with an `F'/F. fabricÒ»×ÖÒÔf×ÖÄ¸¿ªÊ¼.  2 F (music Òô) the fourth note in the scale of C major  C´óµ÷Òô½×ÖĞµÄµÚËÄÒô»òÒô·û.
F

fact

factory
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Factory, mill, plant and works all refer to industrial buildings or places but they indicate different products or processes. *factory¡¢ mill¡¢ plant¡¢ works¾ùÖ¸¹¤ÒµµÄ½¨ÖşÎï»ò³¡Ëù, µ«Æä²úÆ·»ò¼Ó¹¤³ÌĞòÔò²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬. Factory is the most common word for the buildings where products are manufactured or assembled *factoryÒ»´Ê×îÎªÆÕÍ¨, Ö¸²úÆ·Éú²ú»ò×°ÅäµÄ¹¤³§: a car, shoe, bottle, etc factory Æû³µÖÆÔì¡¢ ÖÆĞ¬¡¢ ÖÆÆ¿µÈ¹¤³§ *  factory workers ¹¤³§¹¤ÈË. Works suggests a larger group of buildings and machinery, generally not producing finished goods *worksÒâÎª½Ï´óµÄ½¨ÖşÎïÈº¼°Æä»úÆ÷Éè±¸, Ò»°ã²¢²»Éú²ú³ÉÆ·: a gasworks, ironworks ÃºÆø³§¡¢ ¸ÖÌú³§. Plant is more common in US English and relates especially to industrial processes *plant¶àÓÃì¶ÃÀÊ½Ó¢Óï, ÓÈÎª¹¤Òµ¼Ó¹¤Õß: a power, chemical plant ·¢µç³§¡¢ »¯¹¤³§. Mill has the most limited meaning, relating to the processing of certain raw materials *millµÄÒâË¼×îÎªÏÁÕ­, ÏŞÓÃì¶Ä³Ğ©Ô­²ÄÁÏµÄ¼Ó¹¤: a paper/cotton/woollen/steel mill ÔìÖ½[ÃŞ·Ä/Ã«·Ä/¸Ö]³§.

fair

fairly
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The adverbs fairly, quite, rather and pretty can all mean `moderately', `to some extent' or `not very' and are used to alter the strength of adjectives and adverbs. *fairly¡¢ quite¡¢ rather¡¢ prettyÕâ¼¸¸ö¸±´Ê¾ù¿É±íÊ¾£àÊÊ¶ÈµØ£§¡¢ £àÔÚÄ³ÖÖ³Ì¶ÈÉÏ£§»ò£à²»ºÜ£§µÄÒâË¼, ³£ÓÃÒÔ¸Ä±äËùĞŞÊÎµÄĞÎÈİ´Ê»ò¸±´ÊµÄ·ÖÁ¿. Fairly is the weakest and pretty the strongest and most informal, but their effect is very much influenced by intonation. *fairly´ÊÒå×îÈõ¶øpretty´ÊÒå×îÇ¿, Ò²×îÍ¨Ë×, µ«´ÊÒåµÄÇ¿ÈõÊÜÓïµ÷µÄÓ°ÏìºÜ´ó. Generally, the more any of these adverbs is stressed, the more negative the sentence sounds. Ò»°ãËµÀ´, ÕâÀà¸±´Ê¶ÁµÃÔ½ÖØ, ¾ä×ÓÌıÆğÀ´·ñ¶¨º¬Òå¾ÍÔ½Ç¿.  1 When rather or pretty is used with a positive quality, it can sound enthusiastic *rather»òprettyÓë°ıÒå´ÊÁ¬ÓÃÊ±, ÌıÆğÀ´ĞÄÇéÓä¿ì: a rather/pretty good play Ò»³öÏà µ±ºÃµÄÏ·. With a negative or variable quality they express disapproval ÕâÁ½¸ö´ÊÓë±áÒå´Ê»ò¿É°ı¿É±áµÄ´ÊÁ¬ÓÃÊ±, ±íÊ¾²»ÔŞ³É»ò²»ÂúÒâ: rather/pretty poor work Ïàµ±²îµÄ¹¤×÷ *  I'm rather/pretty warm. ÎÒºÜÈÈ. *  It's rather/pretty small/big. Õâ¿ÉÌ«Ğ¡[´ó]ÁË.  2 Fairly is mostly used with positive qualities *fairly¶àÓë°ıÒå´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ: fairly tidy, spacious, friendly, etc Í¦Õû½à¡¢ ¿í³¨¡¢ÈÈÇéµÈ (compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: rather untidy, cramped, unfriendly, etc ºÜÁãÂÒ¡¢ ÏÁÕ­¡¢ Àäµ­µÈ).  3 Only rather can be used with comparative expressions and too Ö»ÓĞrather¿ÉÓë±È½Ï¼¶µÄ´ÊÓïºÍtooÁ¬ÓÃ: The house is rather bigger than we thought. ÕâËù·¿×Ó±ÈÎÒÃÇÏëµÄ´óµÃ¶à. *  These shoes are rather too small. ÕâË«Ğ¬Î´ÃâÌ«Ğ¡ÁË.  4 Rather and quite can precede the indefinite article when followed by an adjective + noun *ratherºÍquiteÓë£à²»¶¨¹Ú´Ê+ĞÎÈİ´Ê+Ãû´Ê£§Á¬ÓÃÊ±, ¿ÉÖÃì¶²»¶¨¹Ú´ÊÖ®Ç°: rather/quite a nice day Ê®·ÖÇçÀÊµÄÒ»Ìì *  a rather/quite/fairly/pretty nice day Ê®·ÖÇçÀÊµÄÒ»Ìì. See also note on usage at quite Áí¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨.

faith

fall

fan
/ fAn; fAn/ v (-nn-)  1 [Tn] make a current of air blow onto (sb/sth) with or as if with a fan ¡¡£¨Ä³ÈË[Ä³Îï]£©: cool one's face by fanning it with a newspaper ÓÃ±¨Ö½¡¡·çÊ¹Á³Á¹¿ì * fan a fire, ie to make it burn more strongly ¡¡»ğ.  2 [Tn] blow gently on (sb/sth) ĞìĞì´µÔÚ£¨Ä³ÈË[Ä³Îï]£©ÉÏ: The breeze fanned our faces. Î¢·çÇáÇá´µÔÚÎÒÃÇµÄÁ³ÉÏ.  3 [Tn, Tn.p] ~ sth (out) spread (esp playing-cards) in the form of a fan Õ¹³ÉÉÈĞÎ£¨ÓÈÖ¸Ö½ÅÆ£©: He fanned (out) the cards in his hand before playing. far
/ fB:(r); fBr/ adv (farther/ 5fB:TE(r); `fBrTL/ or further/ 5f\:TE(r); `f[TL/, farthest/ 5fB:TIst; `fBrTIst/ or furthest/ 5f\:TIst; `f[TIst/)  1 (usu in questions and negative sentences Í¨³£ÓÃì¶ÒÉÎÊ¾äºÍ·ñ¶¨¾ä) (of space) at or to a great distance £¨Ö¸¿Õ¼ä£©Ô¶: How far is it to London from here? ´ÓÕâÀïµ½Â×¶ØÓĞ¶àÔ¶? ÎÒÃÇ³Ë»ğ³µµ½Â×¶Ø, È»áá»»³¤Í¾Æû³µ. as/so far as (a) the same distance as Óë...µÄ¾àÀëÏàµÈ: We didn't go so far as the others. ÎÒÃÇ×ßµÃ²»ÈçÆäËûÈËÔ¶. Ëû¸¸Ä¸½ß¾¡È«Á¦¸§ÑøËû. (c) (of progress) up to a specified point but not beyond £¨Ö¸½øÕ¹£©´ïµ½Ä³Ò»µãÎªÖ¹: We've got as far as collecting our data but we haven't analysed it yet. ÎÒÃÇÒÑÊÕ¼¯ÁË×ÊÁÏ, µ«ÉĞÎ´·ÖÎö. as/so far as in me `lies (fml ÎÄ) to the best of my ability; as much as I can ¾¡ÎÒËùÄÜ; ¾¡ÎÒµÄÁ¦Á¿. as/so far as it, etc `goes to a limited extent, usu less than desirable ´ïµ½Ò»¶¨³Ì¶È£¨Í¨³£²¢Î´ÈçÔ¸£©: Your plan is a good one as far as it goes, but there are several points you've forgotten to consider. ÄãµÄ¼Æ»­Ä¿Ç°¿´À´»¹Ëã²»´í, µ«ÓĞ¼¸µãÄãÍüÁË¿¼ÂÇ½øÈ¥. as/so far as sb/sth is concerned in the way, or to the extent, that sb/sth is involved or affected ¾ÍÄ³ÈË[Ä³ÊÂÎï]¶øÑÔ: The rise in interest rates will be disastrous as far as small firms are concerned. ËıÏÔÈ»ÊÇ×îºÃµÄ. carry/take sth too, etc `far continue (doing) sth beyond reasonable limits ×öµÃ¹ı·Ö: Don't be such a prude  you can carry modesty too far! ±ğÄÇ÷á¾Ğ½÷--ÄãÇ«ĞéµÃÌ«¹ı·ÖÁË! * It's time to be serious; you've carried this joke far enough. ¸ÃÑÏËàĞ©ÁË, Õâ¸öÍæĞ¦Äã¿ªµÃ²î²»¶àÁË. far/farther/further afield => afield. far and a`way (preceding comparative or superlative adjs ÓÃì¶ĞÎÈİ´ÊµÄ±È½Ï¼¶»ò×î¸ß¼¶Ö®Ç°) by a very great amount; very much ¼«; ·Ç³£: She's far and away the best actress I've seen. ËıÊÇÎÒËù¼ûµ½µÄ×îºÃµÄÑİÔ±. far and `near/`wide everywhere; from or to a large area µ½´¦; ËÄÃæ°Ë·½: They searched far and wide for the missing child. ËûÃÇµ½´¦Ñ°ÕÒÊ§×ÙµÄĞ¡º¢. * People came from far and near to hear the famous violinist. ÈËÃÇ´ÓËÄÃæ°Ë·½¸ÏÀ´ÌıÕâÎ»ÖøÃûĞ¡ÌáÇÙ¼ÒµÄÑİ×à. far be it from me to do sth (but...) ÎÒºÁÎŞ×öÄ³ÊÂÎïµÄÒâË¼£¨µ«...£©: Far be it from me to interfere in your affairs but I would like to give you just one piece of advice. ÎÒ¾öÎŞÒâ¸ÉÉæÄãµÄÊÂ, µ«ÎÒÖ»Ïë¸øÄãÌá¸ö½¨Òé. far from doing sth instead of doing sth £¨²»µ«£©²»×öÄ³ÊÂÎï£¨·´¶ø...£©: Far from enjoying dancing, he loathes it. ËûÆñÖ¹²»Ï²»¶, ¼òÖ±ÌÖÑáÌøÎè. far from sth/from doing sth not at all sth; almost the opposite of sth ºÁ²»; Ò»µãÒ²²»; Ô¶·Ç; ¼¸ºõÓëÖ®Ïà·´: The problem is far from easy, ie is in fact very difficult. ÕâÎÊÌâ¾ø·ÇÒ×ÊÂ. * Your account is far from (being) true/is far from the truth. ÄãËùËµÔ¶·ÇÊÂÊµ. far `from it (infml ¿Ú) certainly not; almost the opposite µ±È»²»; Ò»µãÒ²²»; ¼¸ºõÏà·´: `Are you happy here?' `No, far from it; I've never been so miserable in my life.' £àÄãÔÚÕâÀïÓä¿ìÂğ?£§£àÒ»µãÒ²²»Óä¿ì, ÎÒ´ÓÀ´Ã»ÏñÏÖÔÚÕâÑùÄÑÊÜ¹ı.£§ few and far between => few. go as/so far as to do sth/as that, etc be willing to go to extreme limits in dealing with sth ´¦ÀíÄ³ÊÂÎïÊ±Ô¸×ß¼«¶Ë; ÉõÖÁ×öµ½Ä³µØ²½: I won't go so far as to say that he is dishonest, ie I won't actually accuse him of dishonesty, even though I might suspect him of it. ÎÒ»¹²»ÏëËµËû²»³ÏÊµ£¨×İÈ»ÎÒÓĞËù»³ÒÉ, Ò²²»Ô¸ÒâÕâÑùÖ¸ÔğËû£©. go `far (a) (of money) buy many goods, etc £¨Ö¸Ç®£©¿ÉÂòĞí¶à¶«Î÷: A pound doesn't go very far (ie You can't buy very much for a pound) nowadays. farther
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Further is now more common than farther in British English. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ÏÖÔÚfurther±ÈfartherÓÃµÃ¸üÆÕ±é. They can both be used in relation to distance ÕâÁ½¸ö´Ê¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¾àÀë: I can throw much further/farther than you. ÎÒÈÓµÃ±ÈÄãÔ¶µÃ¶à. *  Bristol is further/farther than Oxford. ²¼ÀïË¹ÍĞ¶û±ÈÅ£½òÔ¶. In US English farther is usually used in relation to distance. ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞfartherÍ¨³£ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¾àÀë. In British and US English only further can be used to indicate addition ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, Ö»ÓĞfurther¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾£à¸ü¼Ó£§»ò£à½øÒ»²½£§µÄÒâË¼: Are there any further questions? »¹ÓĞÎÊÌâÂğ? *  a College of Further Education ½øĞŞÑ§Ôº.

adv  1 quickly ¿ìµØ; Ñ¸ËÙµØ: Can't you run any faster than that? Äã²»ÄÜÅÜµÃÔÙ¿ìµãÂğ? * Night was fast approaching. ºÚÒ¹×ªË²¶øÖÁ.  2 (idm Ï°Óï) run, etc as fast as one's legs can carry one as fast as one is able ¾¡¿ìµØ£¨ÅÜµÈ£©.

fat
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Fat is the most usual and direct adjective to describe people with excess flesh, but it is not polite *fatÊÇÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈË·ÊÅÖµÄ×î³£ÓÃ¡¢ ×îÖ±½ÓµÄĞÎÈİ´Ê, µ«º¬±áÒå: That suit's too tight -- it makes you look really fat. ÄÇÌ×ÒÂ·şÌ«Êİ--ÏÔµÃÄãºÜÅÖ. More insulting are flabby, which suggests loose flesh, and podgy, used especially of fingers and hands. ±áÒå¸üÇ¿µÄ´ÊÊÇflabby£¨Ö¸¼¡ÈâËÉ³Ú£©ºÍpodgy£¨ÓÈÖ¸ÊÖÖ¸ºÍÊÖ£©. To be polite we can use plump, suggesting slight or attractive fatness, or stout, indicating overall heaviness of the body. ½ÏÀñÃ²Ğ©¿ÉÓÃplump£¨Ö¸ÉÔÅÖ»ò·áÂú£©»òstout£¨Ö¸ÉíÌåÅÖµÃÔÈ³Æ£©. Tubby is often used in a friendly way of people who are also short, and chubby indicates pleasant roundness in babies and cheeks. *tubby³£ÓÃÒÔÖ¸°«ÅÖµÄÈË, º¬Ç×ÇĞ¸Ğ, ¶øchubbyÔòÓÃì¶Ó¤¶ùºÍÁ³¼Õ, ÒâÎªÔ²ÅÖ¶ø¿É°®. The most neutral term is overweight, while doctors use obese to describe people who are so overweight that they are unhealthy. ×îÎŞ°ı±áº¬ÒåµÄ´ÊÊÇoverweight, Ò½ÉúÔòÓÃobeseÖ¸ÅÖµÃ³Ê²¡Ì¬µÄÈË.

/ fi:l; fil/ v (pt, pp felt / felt; fZlt/)  1 [Tn, Tw] explore or perceive (sth) by touching or by holding in the hands Ãş, ´¥, ´¥Ãş£¨Ä³Îï£©: feel a rock, a piece of cloth, etc ÃşÃşÊ¯Í·¡¢ ²¼µÈ * Can you feel the bump on my head? ÎÒÃÇ¶¼¾õµÃËıµÄÂÛ¾İºÜÓĞÁ¦. * Don't you feel the beauty of the countryside? ÄãÊÇ²»ÊÇ¾õµÃ½¼ÍâµÄ¾°É«ºÜÃÀÑ½?  7 [I] be capable of sensation ÄÜ¸Ğ¾õ; ÓĞÖª¾õ: The dead cannot feel. feel
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are several verbs relating to the five senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste and touch. ÓĞ¼¸¸ö¶¯´ÊÓëÊÓ¾õ¡¢ Ğá¾õ¡¢ Ìı¾õ¡¢ Î¶¾õ¡¢ ´¥¾õÕâÎåÖÖ¸Ğ¹ÙÓĞ¹Ø. They are often used with the verb can. ÕâĞ©¶¯´Ê³£ÓëcanÁ¬ÓÃ. Normally, only the simple tenses are used. Í¨³£Ö»ÓÃì¶¼òµ¥Ê±Ì¬.  1 See, smell, hear, taste and feel indicate the experiencing of something through one of the senses *see¡¢ smell¡¢ hear¡¢ taste¡¢ feel·Ö±ğ±íÊ¾ÎåÖÖ¸Ğ¹ÙÖ®Ò»¶ÔÄ³ÎïµÄ¸ĞÖª: He saw a light in the window. Ëû¿´¼û´°»§ÀïÓĞµÆ¹â. *  I heard an explosion last night. ÎÒ×òÍíÌıµ½ÁË±¬Õ¨Éù. *  I can smell gas. ÎÒÎÅµ½ÓĞÃºÆøÎ¶.  2 These verbs can also indicate somebody's physical ability to perceive with the senses ÕâĞ©¶¯´Ê»¹¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä³ÈËµÄ¸Ğ¹ÙÄÜÁ¦: He can't see, hear, etc very well. ËûµÄÊÓÁ¦¡¢ ÌıÁ¦µÈ²»Ì«ºÃ.  3 Look, smell, taste, sound and feel are used to describe how somebody or something is experienced through one of the senses, usually in one of these patterns *look¡¢ smell¡¢ taste¡¢ sound¡¢ feel¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Í¨¹ıÎå¹ÙÖ®Ò»¸ĞÖªÄ³ÈË»òÄ³ÊÂÎï, Í¨³£ÓÃì¶ÏÂÁĞ¾äĞÍ: (a) She looks happy, ie She's smiling. Ëı¿´ÉÏÈ¥ºÜ¸ßĞË. (b) The wine tastes like water, ie It's very weak. Õâ¾ÆµÄÎ¶µÀÏñË®Ò»Ñù. (c) The singer sounds as though she's got a sore throat, ie The sound of her voice suggests that she has a sore throat. Õâ¸èÊÖµÄÉùÒôÌıÆğÀ´ºÃÏñËıÉ¤×ÓÌÛ.  4 Look, smell, listen, taste, feel can indicate that somebody is making a deliberate effort to perceive something *look¡¢ smell¡¢ listen¡¢ taste¡¢ feel¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä³ÈËÖøÒâÒª¸ĞÖªÄ³ÊÂÎï: (a) `I can't see the spot.' `Well look harder.' £àÎÒ¿´²»µ½ÓĞ°ßµã.£§£àÔÙºÃºÃ¿´¿´.£§ (b) `I can't hear any music.' `Listen carefully.' £àÎÒÌı²»³öÓĞÒôÀÖ.£§£àÔÙÓÃĞÄÌıÌı.£§ (c) `I can't taste anything.' `Try tasting this.' £àÎÒ³¢²»³öÓĞÊ²÷áÎ¶µÀ.£§£àÔÙ³¢³¢Õâ¸ö.£§  5 Feel and look can express the physical or emotional state of a person. *feelºÍlook¿É±íÊ¾ÈËµÄÉíÌå»òÇéĞ÷µÄ×´Ì¬. Here, the continuous tenses can be used ÔÚÕâÖÖÇé¿öÏÂ¿ÉÓÃ½øĞĞÊ±Ì¬: I feel sick,nervous, disappointed, etc. ÎÒ¸Ğµ½²»Êæ·ş¡¢ ½ôÕÅ¡¢ Ê§ÍûµÈ.*  He was feeling tired so he didn't come to the party. Ëû¸Ğµ½ºÜÀÛ, ËùÒÔÃ»À´²Î¼Ó¾Û»á. *  You're looking happy. Have you had good news? Äã¿´À´ºÜ¸ßĞË. ÓĞºÃÏûÏ¢Âğ?
feel
/ fi:l; fil/ n [sing]  1 act of feeling Ãş; ´¥; ´¥Ãş: Let me have a feel. feet

foot
/ fUt; fJt/ n (pl feet/ fi:t; fit/)  1 [C] lowest part of the leg, below the ankle, on which a person or animal stands ½Å; ×ã: He rose to his feet, ie stood up. ËûÕ¾ÆğÉíÀ´. * walking round the house in bare feet, ie not wearing socks, shoes, etc ¹â½ÅÎ§Öø·¿×Ó×ß * [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] a foot switch, brake, pump, etc, ie operated by one's foot, not one's hand ½ÅÌ¤¿ª¹Ø¡¢ ½ÅÉ·³µ¡¢ ½ÅÌ¤±Ã. =>illus ¼û²åÍ¼.  2 [C usu sing Í¨³£×÷µ¥Êı] part of a sock, stocking, etc that covers the foot £¨Íà×ÓµÈµÄ£©×ã²¿.  3 [C] (pl feet or, in informal use and attributively, ÓÃì¶¿ÚÓï»ò×÷¶¨ÓïÊ±, Òà×÷ foot) (abbr ËõĞ´ ft) measure of length: 12 inches £¨³¤¶Èµ¥Î»£©Ó¢³ß£¨12Ó¢´ç£©: We're flying at 35000 feet. ÎÒÃÇ·ÉĞĞµÄ¸ß¶ÈÊÇ35000Ó¢³ß. * `How tall are you?'`Five foot nine', ie five feet and nine inches. £àÄãÉí¸ß¶àÉÙ?£§£àÎåÓ¢³ß¾ÅÓ¢´ç.£§ * [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] a 6-foot high wall 6Ó¢³ß¸ßµÄÇ½. =>App 4,5 ¼û¸½Â¼4¡¢ 5.  4 [sing] the ~ of sth (a) the lowest part of sth; base or bottom of sth £¨Ä³ÎïµÄ£©×îÏÂ²¿, µ×²¿: at the foot of the stairs ÔÚÂ¥Ìİµ×²¿ * They camped at the foot of the mountain. -footer
/ fUtE(r); `fJtL/ (forming compounds ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸´ºÏ´Ê) person or thing of the specified length, height or width Ä³Ò»³¤¶È¡¢ ¸ß¶È¡¢ ¿í¶ÈµÄÈË»òÎï: a six-footer, ie a person who is six feet tall or thing that is six feet wide or long.

female
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 (a) Male and female are nouns and adjectives used to indicate the sex of living things *maleºÍfemale¼È¿É×÷Ãû´ÊÒ²¿É×÷ĞÎÈİ´Ê, ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾ÉúÎïµÄĞÔ±ğ: a male/female giraffe, bird, sardine, child, flower, etc ¹«[Ä¸]³¤¾±Â¹¡¢ Äñ¡¢ É³¶¡Óã; ÄĞ[Å®]º¢×Ó; ĞÛĞÔµÄ[´ÆĞÔµÄ]»¨µÈ *  The males in the herd protect the females and the young. ÊŞÈºÖĞµÄĞÛĞÔ¶¯Îï±£»¤´ÆĞÔ¶¯ÎïºÍÓ××Ğ. (b) When speaking of humans the adjectives male/female refer especially to the physical features of one sex or the other *male/female×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃì¶ÈËÊ±, ÓÈÖ¸ÄĞÅ®µÄĞÔ±ğÌØáç: The male voice is deeper than the female. ÄĞĞÔµÄÉ¤Òô±ÈÅ®ĞÔµÄµÍ³Á. *  the female figure Å®ĞÔµÄÉí²Ä. (c) When speaking about occupations, we usually say: a woman doctor/women doctors (NOT a female doctor/female doctors, though we do say a male doctor, NOT a man doctor). Ì¸µ½ÄĞÅ®µÄ Ö°Òµ, Í¨³£Ëµ: a woman doctor/ women doctors£¨²»¿ÉËµa female doctor/ female doctors, µ«È´Ò»¶¨ÒªËµa male doctor, ¶ø²»¿ÉËµa man doctor£©. (d) The nouns male/female should not be used to refer to people (as opposed to their qualities, etc) *male/female×÷Ãû´ÊÊ±²»ÄÜÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈË. They can give offence, esp female. ÓÃì¶Ö¸ÈËÊ±»áÒıÆğ·´¸Ğ, ÓÈÆäÊÇfemaleÒ»´Ê. We use man/woman instead ÕâÊ±ÒªÓÃman/woman: Men have more body hair than women. ÄĞÈËµÄº®Ã«±ÈÅ®ÈËµÄ¶à.  2 (a) Masculine and feminine are adjectives used to describe the behaviour, appearance, etc considered normal or acceptable for humans of one sex or the other. *masculineºÍfeminineÎªĞÎÈİ´Ê, ÓÃÒÔÃèÊöËùÎ½Õı³£µÄ»ò¹«ÈÏµÄÄĞÅ®Ö®±ğ, ÈçĞĞÎª¡¢ ÍâÃ²µÈ. They can therefore be used of the `opposite' sex: a man can be described as feminine but not female ĞÎÈİÄĞÈË¿ÉÓÃfeminine¶ø²»¿ÉÓÃfemale: She dresses in a very feminine way. Ëı´©µÃ·Ç³£Å®ĞÔ»¯. * She has a deep masculine voice. ËıµÄÉùÒôÏñÄĞÈËµÄÄÇÑùµÍ³Á. (b) As nouns and adjectives masculine and feminine (as well as neuter) indicate grammatical gender. *masculineºÍfeminine£¨ÒÔ¼°neuter£©×÷Ãû´ÊºÍĞÎÈİ´Ê, ·Ö±ğÓÃÒÔÖ¸Óï·¨ÖĞµÄÑôĞÔºÍÒõĞÔ£¨ÒÔ¼°ÖĞĞÔ£©.

field
/ fi:ld; fild/ n  1 area of land (usu enclosed by a fence, hedge, etc) used for pasturing animals or cultivating crops Ìï; µØ; ÄÁ³¡: working in the fields ÔÚÌï¼ä¸É»î * a fine field of wheat Ò»Æ¬ºÃÂóÌï.  2 (usu in compounds Í¨³£ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸´ºÏ´Ê) (a) wide area or expanse ÁÉÀ«µÄµØ·½; Ô­Ò°; ¿õÒ°: an `ice-field, eg around the North Pole. fight

ÎÒÃÇÔÚÈğÊ¿¶È¹ıÁËÒ»¸öÓä¿ìµÄ¼ÙÆÚ. * (ironic ·´Óï) This is a fine mess we're in! ºÃÒ»¸öÂÒÌ¯×Ó!  2 (of weather) bright; clear; not raining £¨Ö¸ÌìÆø£©ÇçÀÊµÄ, ÎŞÔÆµÄ, ÎŞÓêµÄ: It poured all morning, but turned fine later. É³×Ó±ÈËéÊ¯Ï¸.  4 slender; thin ÏËÏ¸µÄ; Ï¸Ğ¡µÄ: fine thread Ï¸Ïß * a pencil with a fine point ºÜ¼âµÄÇ¦±Ê.  5 (of metals) refined; pure £¨Ö¸½ğÊô£©¾«Á¶µÄ, ´¿µÄ: fine gold ´¿½ğ.  6 (a) difficult to perceive; subtle ÄÑì¶²ì¾õµÄ; Ï¸Î¢µÄ: You are making very fine distinctions. fineness 
n [U].

finite

first
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When ordering items in a list, first(ly), second(ly), third(ly), etc are put at the beginning of the sentence or clause. ÔÚÁĞ¾ÙÏîÄ¿Ê±, Òª½«first(ly)¡¢ second(ly)¡¢ third(ly)µÈ´ÊÖÃì¶¾ä×Ó»ò´Ó¾äÖ®Ê×. They are usually followed by a comma. ÔÚÕâĞ©´ÊááÃæÍ¨³£ÓÃ¶ººÅ. Some speakers prefer first to firstly ÓĞĞ©ÈËËµ»°Ê±Ô¸ÓÃfirst¶ø²»ÓÃfirstly: There are three reasons for my resignation. First(ly), I am dissatisfied with my wages; secondly, the hours are too long; and thirdly, there is little chance of promotion. ÎÒ´ÇÖ°ÓĞÈı¸öÔ­Òò. Ò»ÊÇÎÒ¶Ô¹¤×Ê²»ÂúÒâ; ¶şÊÇ¹¤×÷Ê±¼äÌ«³¤; ÈıÊÇ¼¸ºõÃ»ÓĞ½úÉı»ú»á. Alternatively, first, second, third, etc could be used. ÔÚÉÏÊöÕâÀà¾ä×ÓÖĞÒ²¿ÉÊ¹ÓÃfirst¡¢ second¡¢ thirdµÈ.

/ fIt; fIt/ v (-tt-, pt, pp fitted; US also fit)  1 (a) [I, Tn] be the right shape and size for (sb) ĞÎ×´¼°´óĞ¡¶Ô£¨Ä³ÈË£©ºÏÊÊ; ºÏÉí: These shoes don't fit (me). fit

flight
/ flaIt; flaIt/ n  1 [C, U] act or instance of fleeing or running away ÌÓ; ÌÓ±Ü; ÌÓÅÜ: Many soldiers fell wounded in their flight from the defeat. flooding

flood
/ flQd; flQd/ n  1 (a) (coming of a) great quantity of water, esp over a place that is usu dry ´óÁ¿µÄË®; ºéË®; Ë®ÔÖ: The heavy rain caused floods in the houses by the river. floor
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In British English the floor of a building at street level is the ground floor and the floor above that is the first floor. fog
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Fog, mist and haze are all clouds of water vapour at ground level and above. *fog¡¢ mist¡¢ haze¾ùÎªµØÃæ¼°µØÃæÒÔÉÏµÄË®ÕôÆø. They indicate different degrees of thickness Õâ¼¸¸ö´Ê±íÊ¾µÄÅ¨¶ÈÓĞËù²»Í¬: fog is the thickest and haze the least thick. *fog×îÅ¨, haze×î±¡. Haze also occurs when it is very hot *hazeÔÚÌìÆøÑ×ÈÈÊ±Ò²»á³öÏÖ: a heat-haze ÈÈÌìµÄ±¡Îí. Smog is an unhealthy mixture of smoke and fog in the air of some industrial cities. *smogÊÇÔÚÒ»Ğ©¹¤Òµ³ÇÊĞµÄ¿ÕÆøÖĞÑÌÓëÎíµÄ»ìºÏÎï, ÊÇÓĞº¦ì¶½¡¿µµÄ.

foll
abbr ËõĞ´ = following.
follow
/ 5fClEU; `fBlo/ v  1 (a) [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sth (by/with sth) (cause sth to) come, go or take place after (sb/sth else) (in space, time or order) £¨Ê¹Ä³ÊÂÎï£©£¨ÔÚ¿Õ¼ä¡¢ Ê±¼ä»òË³ĞòÉÏ£©ÔÚ£¨ËûÈË[ËûÊÂÎï]£©Ö®áá, À´¡¢ È¥»ò·¢Éú; ¸úËæ; ¸úÖø: The duckling followed its mother everywhere. fool

/ 5fu:lpru:f; `ful`pruf/ adj  1 not capable of going wrong or of being misunderstood; very plain and simple ²»»á´íµÄ; ²»»áÒıÆğÎó½âµÄ; ·Ç³£¼òµ¥Ã÷ÁËµÄ: a foolproof method, plan, scheme, etc ÍòÎŞÒ»Ê§µÄ·½·¨¡¢ ¼Æ»­¡¢ ·½°¸µÈ.  2 not capable of going wrong or of being used wrongly; reliable and easy to operate ²»»á×ö´íµÄ; ²»»áÓÃ´íµÄ; ¿É¿¿¶ø²Ù×÷¼ò±ãµÄ: a foolproof security system ¿É¿¿µÄ°²È«ÏµÍ³.

force
/ fR:s; fRrs/ v  1 [Tn.pr, Cn.t] make (sb/oneself) do sth he/one does not want to do; compel; oblige Ê¹£¨Ä³ÈË[×Ô¼º]£©×ö²»Ô¸×öµÄÊÂ; Ç¿ÆÈ; ±ÆÆÈ; ÆÈÊ¹: force a confession out of sb ±ÆÄ³ÈËÕĞ¹© * The thief forced her to hand over the money. form

forward
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The suffix -ward means `in the direction of' and forms adverbs and adjectives*-wardÕâÒ»áá×ºÒâÎª£àÏòÖøÄ³·½Ïò£§, ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸±´ÊºÍĞÎÈİ´Ê: forward, backward, westward, homeward, etc ÏòÇ°¡¢ Ïòáá¡¢ ÏòÎ÷¡¢ Ïò¼ÒÀïµÈ. The suffix -wards has the same meaning but only forms adverbs *-wardsÓë-wardÒâË¼ÏàÍ¬µ«Ö»ÄÜ¹¹³É¸±´Ê: forwards, backwards, westwards, homewards, etc ÏòÇ°¡¢ Ïòáá¡¢ ÏòÎ÷¡¢ Ïò¼ÒÀïµÈ. Compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: They turned westward/westwards after crossing the river. ËûÃÇ¹ıºÓÒÔááÏòÎ÷¹ÕÁË. They travelled in a westward direction. ËûÃÇÍùÎ÷×ßÁË. *  He leant forward/forwards to see better. frequency
/ 5fri:kwEnsI; `frikwEnsI/ n  1 [U] (a) rate of occurrence or repetition of sth, usu measured over a particular period of time £¨Ä³ÊÂ·¢Éú»òÖØ¸´µÄ£©ÆµÂÊ: Fatal accidents have decreased in frequency over recent years. ½üÄêÀ´ËÀÍöÊÂ¹Ê·¢ÉúµÄÆµÂÊÒÑ¾­ÏÂ½µ. * the alarming frequency of computer errors ¼ÆËã»ú²î´í¾ªÈËµÄÆµÃÜ. ÎÒÏÅµÃÒªÃü.  2 [C usu sing Í¨³£×÷µ¥Êı] (infml ¿Ú) person or thing that looks ridiculous or unattractive ÆæĞÎ¹Ö×´µÄ»ò²»ÆğÑÛµÄÈË»òÎï: She thinks that dress is pretty  I think she looks a fright in it. frighten
/ 5fraItn; `fraItn/ v  1 [Tn] fill (sb) with fear; make afraid; scare £¨Ê¹Ä³ÈË£©¸Ğµ½¿Ö¾å; Ê¹º¦ÅÂ; ¾ªÏÅ: Sorry, I didn't mean to frighten you. ¶Ô²»Æğ, ÎÒ²»ÊÇ¹ÊÒâÏÅ»£ÄãµÄ. * Loud traffic frightens horses. ³µÁ¾ÔëÒôÊ¹ÂíÊÜ¾ª.  2 (idm Ï°Óï) frighten/scare sb to `death/out of his `wits; frighten the `life out of sb frighten sb very much; terrify or startle sb ¾ªÏÅÄ³ÈË; Ê¹Ä³ÈË¿Ö²À»ò¾ªãµ: The child was frightened to death by the violent thunderstorm. / frCst; ?@ frR:st; frRst/ n  1 (a) [U] weather condition in which the temperature falls below freezing-point, usu accompanied by the formation of frost(2) ÑÏº®£¨ÆøÎÂÔÚ±ùµãÒÔÏÂ, Í¨³£°éÓĞËª¶³£©: Young plants are often killed by frost. full
/ fUl; fJl/ adj (-er, -est)  1 ~ (of sth/sb) (a) holding or containing as much or as many as possible; completely filled ÂúµÄ; ±¥º¬µÄ; ³äÂúµÄ: drawers full to overflowing ³éÌëÂúµÃ×°²»½ø¶«Î÷ * My cup is full. function

function

fact
/ fAkt; fAkt/ n  1 [C] thing that is known to have happened or to be true or to exist ÊÂÊµ; ÕæÏà: No one can deny the fact that fire burns. ÎŞÈËÄÜ·ñÈÏ»ğÄÜÈ¼ÉÕµÄÊÂÊµ. * Poverty and crime are facts. Õâ¹ÊÊÂÓĞÕæÊÂ×÷¸ù¾İ. * It's important to distinguish fact from fiction. °ÑÏÖÊµÓëĞé¹¹Çø·Ö¿ªÀ´ÊÇºÜÖØÒªµÄ.  4 (idm Ï°Óï) accessory before/after the fact => accessory. an accomplished fact => accomplish. blink the fact => blink. as a matter of fact => matter 1. a ,fact of `life thing that cannot be ignored, however unpleasant Éú»îµÄÏÖÊµ£¨¾¡¹ÜÊ¹ÈË²»¿ì, È´²»ÈİºöÊÓµÄÊÂÎï£©: We must all die some time: that's just a fact of life. / fAk5tIFEs; fAk`tIFEs/ adj (fml ÎÄ) deliberately created or developed; unnatural; artificial ¹ÊÒâ´´Ôì»ò·¢Õ¹µÄ; ²»×ÔÈ»µÄ; ÈËÎªµÄ: factitious enthusiasm Ğé¼ÙµÄÈÈÇé * a factitious demand for goods, ie one created artificially by widespread advertising, etc ¶Ô»õÎïĞèÇóµÄ¼ÙÏà£¨ÓÉ¹ã·ºĞû´«µÈÈËÎªÔì³ÉµÄ£©.
de facto
/ 9deI 5fAktEU; de`fAkto/ (Latin À­) existing in actual fact, whether rightly or not Êµ¼ÊÉÏ´æÔÚµÄ£¨²»ÂÛºÏ·¨Óë·ñ£©: a de facto ruler, government, right Êµ¼ÊÉÏ´æÔÚµÄÍ³ÖÎÕß¡¢ Õş¸®¡¢ È¨Àû * Though his kingship was challenged, he continued to rule de facto. ËäÈ»Ëû×ö¹úÍõµÄÉí·ÖÎªÈËÚ¸²¡, µ«ËûÈÔ´óÈ¨ÔÚÎÕ. Cf ²Î¿´ de jure.
ipso facto

factor

factory farm 
farm in which animals are kept and reared in a way designed to produce the maximum yield (of meat, young, milk, eggs, etc) ¹¤³§»¯Å©³¡£¨Îª¸ß²úÊ³ÓÃÈâ¡¢ ÄÌ¡¢ µ°µÈ¶øËÇÑøºÍ·±Ö³ÉüĞóºÍ¼ÒÇİµÄÅ©³¡£©. `factory farming.
factory ship

factory
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Factory, mill, plant and works all refer to industrial buildings or places but they indicate different products or processes. *factory¡¢ mill¡¢ plant¡¢ works¾ùÖ¸¹¤ÒµµÄ½¨ÖşÎï»ò³¡Ëù, µ«Æä²úÆ·»ò¼Ó¹¤³ÌĞòÔò²»¾¡ÏàÍ¬. Factory is the most common word for the buildings where products are manufactured or assembled *factoryÒ»´Ê×îÎªÆÕÍ¨, Ö¸²úÆ·Éú²ú»ò×°ÅäµÄ¹¤³§: a car, shoe, bottle, etc factory Æû³µÖÆÔì¡¢ ÖÆĞ¬¡¢ ÖÆÆ¿µÈ¹¤³§ *  factory workers ¹¤³§¹¤ÈË. Works suggests a larger group of buildings and machinery, generally not producing finished goods *worksÒâÎª½Ï´óµÄ½¨ÖşÎïÈº¼°Æä»úÆ÷Éè±¸, Ò»°ã²¢²»Éú²ú³ÉÆ·: a gasworks, ironworks ÃºÆø³§¡¢ ¸ÖÌú³§. Plant is more common in US English and relates especially to industrial processes *plant¶àÓÃì¶ÃÀÊ½Ó¢Óï, ÓÈÎª¹¤Òµ¼Ó¹¤Õß: a power, chemical plant ·¢µç³§¡¢ »¯¹¤³§. Mill has the most limited meaning, relating to the processing of certain raw materials *millµÄÒâË¼×îÎªÏÁÕ­, ÏŞÓÃì¶Ä³Ğ©Ô­²ÄÁÏµÄ¼Ó¹¤: a paper/cotton/woollen/steel mill ÔìÖ½[ÃŞ·Ä/Ã«·Ä/¸Ö]³§.

fair

fairly
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The adverbs fairly, quite, rather and pretty can all mean `moderately', `to some extent' or `not very' and are used to alter the strength of adjectives and adverbs. *fairly¡¢ quite¡¢ rather¡¢ prettyÕâ¼¸¸ö¸±´Ê¾ù¿É±íÊ¾£àÊÊ¶ÈµØ£§¡¢ £àÔÚÄ³ÖÖ³Ì¶ÈÉÏ£§»ò£à²»ºÜ£§µÄÒâË¼, ³£ÓÃÒÔ¸Ä±äËùĞŞÊÎµÄĞÎÈİ´Ê»ò¸±´ÊµÄ·ÖÁ¿. Fairly is the weakest and pretty the strongest and most informal, but their effect is very much influenced by intonation. *fairly´ÊÒå×îÈõ¶øpretty´ÊÒå×îÇ¿, Ò²×îÍ¨Ë×, µ«´ÊÒåµÄÇ¿ÈõÊÜÓïµ÷µÄÓ°ÏìºÜ´ó. Generally, the more any of these adverbs is stressed, the more negative the sentence sounds. Ò»°ãËµÀ´, ÕâÀà¸±´Ê¶ÁµÃÔ½ÖØ, ¾ä×ÓÌıÆğÀ´·ñ¶¨º¬Òå¾ÍÔ½Ç¿.  1 When rather or pretty is used with a positive quality, it can sound enthusiastic *rather»òprettyÓë°ıÒå´ÊÁ¬ÓÃÊ±, ÌıÆğÀ´ĞÄÇéÓä¿ì: a rather/pretty good play Ò»³öÏà µ±ºÃµÄÏ·. With a negative or variable quality they express disapproval ÕâÁ½¸ö´ÊÓë±áÒå´Ê»ò¿É°ı¿É±áµÄ´ÊÁ¬ÓÃÊ±, ±íÊ¾²»ÔŞ³É»ò²»ÂúÒâ: rather/pretty poor work Ïàµ±²îµÄ¹¤×÷ *  I'm rather/pretty warm. ÎÒºÜÈÈ. *  It's rather/pretty small/big. Õâ¿ÉÌ«Ğ¡[´ó]ÁË.  2 Fairly is mostly used with positive qualities *fairly¶àÓë°ıÒå´ÊÁ¬ÓÃ: fairly tidy, spacious, friendly, etc Í¦Õû½à¡¢ ¿í³¨¡¢ÈÈÇéµÈ (compare ÊÔ±È½Ï: rather untidy, cramped, unfriendly, etc ºÜÁãÂÒ¡¢ ÏÁÕ­¡¢ Àäµ­µÈ).  3 Only rather can be used with comparative expressions and too Ö»ÓĞrather¿ÉÓë±È½Ï¼¶µÄ´ÊÓïºÍtooÁ¬ÓÃ: The house is rather bigger than we thought. ÕâËù·¿×Ó±ÈÎÒÃÇÏëµÄ´óµÃ¶à. *  These shoes are rather too small. ÕâË«Ğ¬Î´ÃâÌ«Ğ¡ÁË.  4 Rather and quite can precede the indefinite article when followed by an adjective + noun *ratherºÍquiteÓë£à²»¶¨¹Ú´Ê+ĞÎÈİ´Ê+Ãû´Ê£§Á¬ÓÃÊ±, ¿ÉÖÃì¶²»¶¨¹Ú´ÊÖ®Ç°: rather/quite a nice day Ê®·ÖÇçÀÊµÄÒ»Ìì *  a rather/quite/fairly/pretty nice day Ê®·ÖÇçÀÊµÄÒ»Ìì. See also note on usage at quite Áí¼ûËù¸½ÓÃ·¨.

fall
/ fR:l; fRl/ v (pt fell / fel; fZl/, pp fallen / 5fR:lEn; `fRlEn/) 1 [I, Ipr, Ip] come or go down from force of weight, loss of balance, etc; descend or drop ÂäÏÂ; µøÂä; ½µÂä; µôÏÂ: The rain was falling steadily. fall
/ fR:l; fRl/ n  1 [C] act or instance of falling ÂäÏÂ; µøÂä; ½µÂä; µôÏÂ: I had a fall (from a horse) and broke my arm. ÎÒ£¨´ÓÂíÉÏ£©µøÏÂÀ´°Ñ¸ì²²Ë¤¶ÏÁË. * That was a nasty fall. false

(d) deliberately made incorrect in order to deceive ÅªĞé×÷¼ÙµÄ; Î±ÔìµÄ: false weights, scales, dice, etc ¼ÙµÄíÀÂë¡¢ ÌìÆ½¡¢ É«×ÓµÈ * a false passport ¼Ù»¤ÕÕ * a false bottom, ie the disguisedbottom of a suitcase, etc concealing a secret compartment£¨ÊÖÌáÏäµÈÃØÃÜ²ØÎïÓÃµÄ£©¼Ùµ×.  3 deliberately meant to deceive; lying ÓĞÒâÆÛÆ­µÄ; ²»³ÏÊµµÄ; ĞéÍıµÄ: false evidence Î±Ö¤ * present false claims to an insurance company Ïò±£ÏÕ¹«Ë¾Ìá³öÎ±ÔìµÄË÷ÅâÒªÇó.  4 ~ (to sb) unfaithful; disloyal ²»ÖÒÊµµÄ; ÎŞĞÅÒåµÄ: a false friend/lover ²»ÖÒÊµµÄÅóÓÑ[ÇéÈË].  5 [attrib ×÷¶¨Óï] inaccurately named ÃüÃû²»×¼È·µÄ: the false acacia, ie not really an acacia tree, despite its name ´Ì»±£¨·ÇÕæÕıµÄ½ğºÏ»¶Ê÷£©.  6 (idm Ï°Óï) a false a`larm warning or panic about sth which does not happen Ğé¼ÙµÄ¾¯±¨; Ğé¾ª: The rumours of a petrol shortage turned out to be a false alarm. far

Ëû¸¸Ä¸½ß¾¡È«Á¦¸§ÑøËû. (c) (of progress) up to a specified point but not beyond £¨Ö¸½øÕ¹£©´ïµ½Ä³Ò»µãÎªÖ¹: We've got as far as collecting our data but we haven't analysed it yet. farther
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Further is now more common than farther in British English. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, ÏÖÔÚfurther±ÈfartherÓÃµÃ¸üÆÕ±é. They can both be used in relation to distance ÕâÁ½¸ö´Ê¾ù¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¾àÀë: I can throw much further/farther than you. ÎÒÈÓµÃ±ÈÄãÔ¶µÃ¶à. *  Bristol is further/farther than Oxford. ²¼ÀïË¹ÍĞ¶û±ÈÅ£½òÔ¶. In US English farther is usually used in relation to distance. ÔÚÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞfartherÍ¨³£ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾¾àÀë. In British and US English only further can be used to indicate addition ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïºÍÃÀÊ½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, Ö»ÓĞfurther¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾£à¸ü¼Ó£§»ò£à½øÒ»²½£§µÄÒâË¼: Are there any further questions? »¹ÓĞÎÊÌâÂğ? *  a College of Further Education ½øĞŞÑ§Ôº.

fat
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Fat is the most usual and direct adjective to describe people with excess flesh, but it is not polite *fatÊÇÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈË·ÊÅÖµÄ×î³£ÓÃ¡¢ ×îÖ±½ÓµÄĞÎÈİ´Ê, µ«º¬±áÒå: That suit's too tight -- it makes you look really fat. ÄÇÌ×ÒÂ·şÌ«Êİ--ÏÔµÃÄãºÜÅÖ. More insulting are flabby, which suggests loose flesh, and podgy, used especially of fingers and hands. ±áÒå¸üÇ¿µÄ´ÊÊÇflabby£¨Ö¸¼¡ÈâËÉ³Ú£©ºÍpodgy£¨ÓÈÖ¸ÊÖÖ¸ºÍÊÖ£©. To be polite we can use plump, suggesting slight or attractive fatness, or stout, indicating overall heaviness of the body. ½ÏÀñÃ²Ğ©¿ÉÓÃplump£¨Ö¸ÉÔÅÖ»ò·áÂú£©»òstout£¨Ö¸ÉíÌåÅÖµÃÔÈ³Æ£©. Tubby is often used in a friendly way of people who are also short, and chubby indicates pleasant roundness in babies and cheeks. *tubby³£ÓÃÒÔÖ¸°«ÅÖµÄÈË, º¬Ç×ÇĞ¸Ğ, ¶øchubbyÔòÓÃì¶Ó¤¶ùºÍÁ³¼Õ, ÒâÎªÔ²ÅÖ¶ø¿É°®. The most neutral term is overweight, while doctors use obese to describe people who are so overweight that they are unhealthy. ×îÎŞ°ı±áº¬ÒåµÄ´ÊÊÇoverweight, Ò½ÉúÔòÓÃobeseÖ¸ÅÖµÃ³Ê²¡Ì¬µÄÈË.

feel
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: There are several verbs relating to the five senses of sight, smell, hearing, taste and touch. ÓĞ¼¸¸ö¶¯´ÊÓëÊÓ¾õ¡¢ Ğá¾õ¡¢ Ìı¾õ¡¢ Î¶¾õ¡¢ ´¥¾õÕâÎåÖÖ¸Ğ¹ÙÓĞ¹Ø. They are often used with the verb can. ÕâĞ©¶¯´Ê³£ÓëcanÁ¬ÓÃ. Normally, only the simple tenses are used. Í¨³£Ö»ÓÃì¶¼òµ¥Ê±Ì¬.  1 See, smell, hear, taste and feel indicate the experiencing of something through one of the senses *see¡¢ smell¡¢ hear¡¢ taste¡¢ feel·Ö±ğ±íÊ¾ÎåÖÖ¸Ğ¹ÙÖ®Ò»¶ÔÄ³ÎïµÄ¸ĞÖª: He saw a light in the window. Ëû¿´¼û´°»§ÀïÓĞµÆ¹â. *  I heard an explosion last night. ÎÒ×òÍíÌıµ½ÁË±¬Õ¨Éù. *  I can smell gas. ÎÒÎÅµ½ÓĞÃºÆøÎ¶.  2 These verbs can also indicate somebody's physical ability to perceive with the senses ÕâĞ©¶¯´Ê»¹¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä³ÈËµÄ¸Ğ¹ÙÄÜÁ¦: He can't see, hear, etc very well. ËûµÄÊÓÁ¦¡¢ ÌıÁ¦µÈ²»Ì«ºÃ.  3 Look, smell, taste, sound and feel are used to describe how somebody or something is experienced through one of the senses, usually in one of these patterns *look¡¢ smell¡¢ taste¡¢ sound¡¢ feel¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Í¨¹ıÎå¹ÙÖ®Ò»¸ĞÖªÄ³ÈË»òÄ³ÊÂÎï, Í¨³£ÓÃì¶ÏÂÁĞ¾äĞÍ: (a) She looks happy, ie She's smiling. Ëı¿´ÉÏÈ¥ºÜ¸ßĞË. (b) The wine tastes like water, ie It's very weak. Õâ¾ÆµÄÎ¶µÀÏñË®Ò»Ñù. (c) The singer sounds as though she's got a sore throat, ie The sound of her voice suggests that she has a sore throat. Õâ¸èÊÖµÄÉùÒôÌıÆğÀ´ºÃÏñËıÉ¤×ÓÌÛ.  4 Look, smell, listen, taste, feel can indicate that somebody is making a deliberate effort to perceive something *look¡¢ smell¡¢ listen¡¢ taste¡¢ feel¿ÉÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾Ä³ÈËÖøÒâÒª¸ĞÖªÄ³ÊÂÎï: (a) `I can't see the spot.' `Well look harder.' £àÎÒ¿´²»µ½ÓĞ°ßµã.£§£àÔÙºÃºÃ¿´¿´.£§ (b) `I can't hear any music.' `Listen carefully.' £àÎÒÌı²»³öÓĞÒôÀÖ.£§£àÔÙÓÃĞÄÌıÌı.£§ (c) `I can't taste anything.' `Try tasting this.' £àÎÒ³¢²»³öÓĞÊ²÷áÎ¶µÀ.£§£àÔÙ³¢³¢Õâ¸ö.£§  5 Feel and look can express the physical or emotional state of a person. *feelºÍlook¿É±íÊ¾ÈËµÄÉíÌå»òÇéĞ÷µÄ×´Ì¬. Here, the continuous tenses can be used ÔÚÕâÖÖÇé¿öÏÂ¿ÉÓÃ½øĞĞÊ±Ì¬: I feel sick,nervous, disappointed, etc. ÎÒ¸Ğµ½²»Êæ·ş¡¢ ½ôÕÅ¡¢ Ê§ÍûµÈ.*  He was feeling tired so he didn't come to the party. Ëû¸Ğµ½ºÜÀÛ, ËùÒÔÃ»À´²Î¼Ó¾Û»á. *  You're looking happy. Have you had good news? Äã¿´À´ºÜ¸ßĞË. ÓĞºÃÏûÏ¢Âğ?

female
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨:  1 (a) Male and female are nouns and adjectives used to indicate the sex of living things *maleºÍfemale¼È¿É×÷Ãû´ÊÒ²¿É×÷ĞÎÈİ´Ê, ÓÃÒÔ±íÊ¾ÉúÎïµÄĞÔ±ğ: a male/female giraffe, bird, sardine, child, flower, etc ¹«[Ä¸]³¤¾±Â¹¡¢ Äñ¡¢ É³¶¡Óã; ÄĞ[Å®]º¢×Ó; ĞÛĞÔµÄ[´ÆĞÔµÄ]»¨µÈ *  The males in the herd protect the females and the young. ÊŞÈºÖĞµÄĞÛĞÔ¶¯Îï±£»¤´ÆĞÔ¶¯ÎïºÍÓ××Ğ. (b) When speaking of humans the adjectives male/female refer especially to the physical features of one sex or the other *male/female×÷ĞÎÈİ´ÊÓÃì¶ÈËÊ±, ÓÈÖ¸ÄĞÅ®µÄĞÔ±ğÌØáç: The male voice is deeper than the female. ÄĞĞÔµÄÉ¤Òô±ÈÅ®ĞÔµÄµÍ³Á. *  the female figure Å®ĞÔµÄÉí²Ä. (c) When speaking about occupations, we usually say: a woman doctor/women doctors (NOT a female doctor/female doctors, though we do say a male doctor, NOT a man doctor). Ì¸µ½ÄĞÅ®µÄ Ö°Òµ, Í¨³£Ëµ: a woman doctor/ women doctors£¨²»¿ÉËµa female doctor/ female doctors, µ«È´Ò»¶¨ÒªËµa male doctor, ¶ø²»¿ÉËµa man doctor£©. (d) The nouns male/female should not be used to refer to people (as opposed to their qualities, etc) *male/female×÷Ãû´ÊÊ±²»ÄÜÓÃÒÔÖ¸ÈË. They can give offence, esp female. ÓÃì¶Ö¸ÈËÊ±»áÒıÆğ·´¸Ğ, ÓÈÆäÊÇfemaleÒ»´Ê. We use man/woman instead ÕâÊ±ÒªÓÃman/woman: Men have more body hair than women. ÄĞÈËµÄº®Ã«±ÈÅ®ÈËµÄ¶à.  2 (a) Masculine and feminine are adjectives used to describe the behaviour, appearance, etc considered normal or acceptable for humans of one sex or the other. *masculineºÍfeminineÎªĞÎÈİ´Ê, ÓÃÒÔÃèÊöËùÎ½Õı³£µÄ»ò¹«ÈÏµÄÄĞÅ®Ö®±ğ, ÈçĞĞÎª¡¢ ÍâÃ²µÈ. They can therefore be used of the `opposite' sex: a man can be described as feminine but not female ĞÎÈİÄĞÈË¿ÉÓÃfeminine¶ø²»¿ÉÓÃfemale: She dresses in a very feminine way. Ëı´©µÃ·Ç³£Å®ĞÔ»¯. * She has a deep masculine voice. ËıµÄÉùÒôÏñÄĞÈËµÄÄÇÑùµÍ³Á. (b) As nouns and adjectives masculine and feminine (as well as neuter) indicate grammatical gender. *masculineºÍfeminine£¨ÒÔ¼°neuter£©×÷Ãû´ÊºÍĞÎÈİ´Ê, ·Ö±ğÓÃÒÔÖ¸Óï·¨ÖĞµÄÑôĞÔºÍÒõĞÔ£¨ÒÔ¼°ÖĞĞÔ£©.

field

figure
/ 5fIgE(r); ?@ 5fIgjEr; `fI^jL/ v  1 [I, Ipr] ~ (in sth) appear or be mentioned, esp prominently ³öÏÖ»ò±»Ìá¼°£¨ÓÈÖ¸ÒıÈË×¢Ä¿µÄ£©: a character that figures in many of her novels ÔÚËı¶à²¿Ğ¡ËµÖĞ³öÏÖµÄÒ»¸öÈËÎï * She figured conspicuously in the public debate on the issue. fine

fine
/ faIn; faIn/ adv  1 (infml ¿Ú) very well ºÜºÃ: That suits me fine. NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: When ordering items in a list, first(ly), second(ly), third(ly), etc are put at the beginning of the sentence or clause. ÔÚÁĞ¾ÙÏîÄ¿Ê±, Òª½«first(ly)¡¢ second(ly)¡¢ third(ly)µÈ´ÊÖÃì¶¾ä×Ó»ò´Ó¾äÖ®Ê×. They are usually followed by a comma. ÔÚÕâĞ©´ÊááÃæÍ¨³£ÓÃ¶ººÅ. floor
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: In British English the floor of a building at street level is the ground floor and the floor above that is the first floor. ÔÚÓ¢Ê½Ó¢ÓïÖĞ, Â¥·¿µØÃæÓë½ÖµÀÏàÆ½µÄÂ¥²ã½Ğground floor, ground floorÉÏÃæµÄÒ»²ã½Ğfirst floor. *In US English the street-level floor is the first floor and the one above is the second floor. flow
/ flEU; flo/ v (pt, pp -ed)  1 [I, Ipr, Ip] (a) (of a liquid) move freely and continuously £¨Ö¸ÒºÌå£©Á÷¶¯: Her tears flowed freely (down her cheeks). foggy 
adj (-ier, -iest)  1 not clear because of fog; very misty ÓĞÎíµÄ; ÎíÆøÃÉÃÉµÄ: foggy weather ÓĞÎíµÄÌìÆø * a foggy day ÎíÌì.  2 obscure; confused; vague Ä£ºıµÄ; »ìÂÒµÄ; ëüëÊµÄ: His ideas on this subject are a bit foggy. fog
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: Fog, mist and haze are all clouds of water vapour at ground level and above. *fog¡¢ mist¡¢ haze¾ùÎªµØÃæ¼°µØÃæÒÔÉÏµÄË®ÕôÆø. They indicate different degrees of thickness Õâ¼¸¸ö´Ê±íÊ¾µÄÅ¨¶ÈÓĞËù²»Í¬: fog is the thickest and haze the least thick. *fog×îÅ¨, haze×î±¡. Haze also occurs when it is very hot *hazeÔÚÌìÆøÑ×ÈÈÊ±Ò²»á³öÏÖ: a heat-haze ÈÈÌìµÄ±¡Îí. Smog is an unhealthy mixture of smoke and fog in the air of some industrial cities. *smogÊÇÔÚÒ»Ğ©¹¤Òµ³ÇÊĞµÄ¿ÕÆøÖĞÑÌÓëÎíµÄ»ìºÏÎï, ÊÇÓĞº¦ì¶½¡¿µµÄ.

follow
/ 5fClEU; `fBlo/ v  1 (a) [I, Ip, Tn, Tn.pr] ~ sth (by/with sth) (cause sth to) come, go or take place after (sb/sth else) (in space, time or order) £¨Ê¹Ä³ÊÂÎï£©£¨ÔÚ¿Õ¼ä¡¢ Ê±¼ä»òË³ĞòÉÏ£©ÔÚ£¨ËûÈË[ËûÊÂÎï]£©Ö®áá, À´¡¢ È¥»ò·¢Éú; ¸úËæ; ¸úÖø: The duckling followed its mother everywhere. ÓĞÒ»¼Ò´óÒøĞĞÒÑ½µµÍÁËÀûÂÊ, ÆäËûÒøĞĞÒ²×¼»áÕÕÑù×öµÄ. to follow (in a restaurant, etc) as the next course of a meal £¨ÔÚ²Í¹İµÈ£©×÷ÎªÏÂÒ»µÀ²Ë: To follow, we'll have peaches and cream, please. forward
NOTE ON USAGE ÓÃ·¨: The suffix -ward means `in the direction of' and forms adverbs and adjectives*-wardÕâÒ»áá×ºÒâÎª£àÏòÖøÄ³·½Ïò£§, ÓÃÒÔ¹¹³É¸±´ÊºÍĞÎÈİ´Ê: forward, backward, westward, homeward, etc ÏòÇ°¡¢ Ïòáá¡¢ ÏòÎ÷¡¢ Ïò¼ÒÀïµÈ. freeze
/ fri:z; friz/ v (pt froze / frEUz; froz/, pp frozen / 5frEUzn; `frozn/)  1 [I, Tn] (esp of water) change or be changed from liquid to solid by extreme cold £¨ÓÈÖ¸Ë®£©½á±ù; Äı¹Ì: Water freezes at 0C. fresh
